Most Common Android Problems — Android Pitfalls 🐭 🧀

Hello everyone, I hope everything is going well!

In this article, I’m gonna explain Android's common problems and how should we approach them. I’m gonna discuss these problems under the 3 titles; Core, UI, Network.

Let’s get started! 🏁

Core ⚡️

Screen Rotation 🤸🏼‍♀

What does happens when a screen is rotated? Before we think about this question let’s try to understand how does Android deal with that.

When a user rotates their phone the configuration of the Activity changes, so android OS destroys the Activity and recreates it again.

Behind the scenes; when the device orientation changes, first the Activity will disappear for a millisecond when the onPause, onStop, and onDestroy methods are called. After a few milliseconds, the activity will be restarted and the onCreate, onStart, and onResume methods are called.

As seen in the figure above, as the screen rotates, the onCreate method is called again, implying that our old data is lost. This is a common scenario we face when designing Android applications. Without further hesitation, there are two popular ways how to deal with this problem!

  • With the use of View Model: ViewModel classes are designed to hold and manage UI-related data also retains data in configuration changes such as screen rotations. That is why when we use them to keep our state, we do not need to worry about phone rotation.
  • With the use of onSaveInstanceState(): We can store the data in a bundle and retrieve it using the onRestoreInstanceState method.
https://medium.com/media/3581e723c670fc2fa3025e4f1b508edb/href
  • Your Manifest > activity tag add android:configChanges="orientation|keyboardHidden|screenSize": This prevents your activity from being recreated when you rotate or change your orientation, resulting without in any lost data (will retain your previous value)

Fragment null check

The next topic is checking if an activity was created before adding a fragment using fragment manager.

Why do you need to check savedInstanceState parameter whether it’s null or not at onCreate before adding a new fragment? — Answer is here 👉🏻 When your activity is recreated, such as after a screen rotation or other configuration changes, fragments are automatically reattached. By checking if savedInstanceState == null at onCreate you ensure that you are not re-adding a fragment that had already been added for you.

You can use findFragmentByTag or findFragmentById functions to get a fragment. If mentioned methods are returning null then that fragment does not exist. If a fragment exists you don’t have to create a new one, you should use the existing one!

Fragment fragmentA = fragmentManager.findFragmentByTag("frag1");
if (fragmentA == null) {
  // not exist
} else {
  // fragment exist
}

By the way, you don’t need to declare variables reference to Fragment’s instance. Instead, save your fragment by tag then get it. Like that;

https://medium.com/media/012c068f1bc4eb5741708000578e8adb/href

Communicating with Fragments

  • Passing Data between Fragments by Defining Interface: The most common way to pass data between the fragments is by defining an interface with a method that is implemented by the container activity. You can think we have an item of list and item’s details fragments. The list fragment calls the method implemented by the activity and passes the data (item id) to it. The method in the activity finds the item-details fragment and sets the data received from the item fragment by calling a setter method defined in the details fragment.

Let’s look at how to do that!

Firstly, I create an interface called Communicator, there’s a method sendSelectedItemId where we send the selected item’s ids from our ListItem fragment.

https://medium.com/media/af0da0474e6952aab544ca76650421a2/href

We display the new fragment by replacing the ListItemFragment with the DetailFragment in the MainActivity like that;

https://medium.com/media/85ee7b3183f9c25966326f50bf05a290/href

After we have sent the value from the list item fragment, it’s time to retrieve it from our Detail fragment and display it on the screen.

https://medium.com/media/f2c98430c6aab69d8cde9ac5ac1b1dc3/href
  • Passing Data between Fragments using ViewModel: One of the best solutions using ViewModel and LiveData for passing data between two fragments of an activity.

Let’s look at the example;

https://medium.com/media/e4e881f97a0e72eb5774946747a7e650/href

When the user clicks a button, FragmentA will update the live data in ViewModel. The code looks like this;

https://medium.com/media/455310076afc7622db1be0bc6e9798bc/href

Anyone who is observing the selected live data of SharedViewModel can now react to changes in the live data. If FragmentB wants to notice changes, it will look like this:

https://medium.com/media/41c60012cc4956652f6961979e6ec26d/href

The activity also observes the changes;

https://medium.com/media/2250c977539e66c3ae4130ccf9912e0d/href
  • Fragment Result Listener: You can find the best explain how to pass results between fragments by using fragmentResultListener, please read this doc!

UI 🔮

Let’s imagine, you have started to develop the app and you’re gonna show the data on your UI. What kind of situation would we face? 🧐

Let’s look into the first scenario!

No internet connection

You completed your task, fetched the data, and show them on your app, everything is great, but what would the users do if the internet went down?

Consider yourself a user in this scenario. What would you like to see on the screen? Nothing? Previous data? A relevant message?..

I don’t think anyone wants to see anything on the screen. We might show the relevant message, which I believe is better than showing nothing in this scenario, but my approach is “Show previous data!” Let’s have a look at how to do it!

To begin with, in order to do so, the user must use the app at least once while connected to the internet; otherwise, we cannot do so since we need to fetch the data in order to save it!

When a user launches the app for the first time, all data is saved in the database (e.g., SQLite, room, etc…). If the user has an internet connection, previous data that has been stored in the db will be deleted, and then new data (update) will be saved to the db again and again…

That’s great since we’d like to keep the most up-to-date data. When the user does not have an internet connection, we can show the data stored on our app.

https://medium.com/media/7a34751560c8e051460def6ae66abd58/href

But please pay close attention in there, because we need to be careful about which data we show! For example, you may have clothing data (image, detail info, price, size, etc) Which field would you like to show? I prefer not to display clothing prices because they may change during no internet connection. I would only share the image, detail, and size of the clothes which are kinda static information.

https://medium.com/media/d3ae19b880f9c30f16c73fe66debe773/href

What if your data come null?

Let’s go over this scenario. You’ve fetched the data and listed them on the UI, everything looks to be in order, but what if some data is null?! What do you expect to see on the screen as a user?

Actually, as a user, I’d prefer to see something rather than nothing!
As a developer, I would show the information image if the image data comes null, for the text data I would show the information text like ‘Sorry, we couldn’t find the size info’ or ‘N/A’

Please keep in mind that we do not manage service data, but we could show it more clearly.

You can see how I handle it in this code piece 👇🏻

https://medium.com/media/9fde1e3d71405d75dd093dbd4942e2fb/href

Ui State (Loading, Success, Error)

We made a request to the service and are awaiting a response; therefore, What would your approach be in this case (until you receive a response from the service)? Would you simply wait for the response or would you inform the user of the situation?

If I were a user, if I didn’t see a change on the screen until I got a response from the service, I’d think the app was frozen and wouldn’t work, and I’d quit it.

As a developer, I would take the following approach in such a situation: First of all, regardless of the service’s response (Success, Error), we must provide the message that the user should wait for, namely the loading message. If the result is an error, we must show the identical error message to the user. If our service result is successful, we must show our data.

In my example, I used MVVM architecture, therefore I updated my UI state within ProductViewModel class. When the UI state was triggered, I also called the bindApiStatus function.

https://medium.com/media/f5b05d4f982caf8fa6f13607563f2ad2/hrefhttps://medium.com/media/50f32125a5fc837dee1f395643745811/href

Another issue, in this case, is the Loading status. We made a request to the service, and the process from then, until we get a response, is our loading state life cycle.

So, let’s imagine we have a scenario where we have products and list them, and when a user clicks on one of them, it takes them to the product’s detail page. Where should I put the Loading state in this case? 🧐 Please share your thoughts on the comments!

Network ⛓

SSL Pinning

What is SSL? — SSL Pinning stands for Secure Sockets Layer. SSL is the standard security technology for establishing an encrypted link between a client and a server. SSL certificates have a key pair, which is a Public and Private key.

Why do you need SSL Certificate Pinning? — SSL pinning allows the application to only trust the valid or pre-defined certificate or Public Key. The application developer uses the SSL pinning technique as an additional security layer for application traffic. As normally, the application trusts a custom certificate and allows the application to intercept the traffic.

Pinning the set of trusted certificates prevents attackers from analysing the server communication.

I’ve added some articles about SSL Pinning under the References section that I highly recommend you read. You can learn more about it here!

ProGuard-Android

ProGuard is a program that can help you minify, obfuscate, and optimize your code. It is notably effective for reducing the overall size of your Android application as well as deleting unused classes and methods that contribute to Android apps’ inherent 64k method limit. Because of this, ProGuard is frequently suggested for use in both development and production, particularly for larger projects.

ProGuard can be activated for any building type by specifying the minifyEnabled parameter. It is strongly advised that if you intend to use it for production, you also enable it in your development. You may experience unexpected crashes or circumstances where the app does not perform as expected if you do not thoroughly test ProGuard on your development builds.

https://medium.com/media/fb1c3802725c2c1031d5c2d8f35b28ee/href

The Android SDK includes ProGuard as well as the default settings file, which is named proguard-android.txt. It is critical to include this file because it includes explicit configuration settings such as specifying clearly that all View getter and setter methods should not be removed. The file that you will use to configure is proguard-rules.pro.

Thank you for reading. I hope you find it helpful 😌 Please feel free to contact me on Github and LinkedIn. See you soon!

title_detail.value: How to generate Kotlin DSL Client by GraphQL schema

entries.author: Dmitry Ermakov

content.value:
Introducing the Kobby Plugin — a code generator of Kotlin GraphQL Client

On the one hand, the GraphQL schema uniquely defines the data model and the available operations of the service that implements it. On the other hand, Kotlin provides amazing opportunities for creating your own domain-specific languages (DSL). This way, you can write a domain-specific language to interact with your GraphQL service according to the published GraphQL schema. But writing such a code manually is Sisyphean labor. This is where the Kobby Plugin comes in, which can parse your service’s GraphQL schema and generate a client DSL for interaction. Let’s try it out!

The source code for the examples in this article is available in Kobby Gradle Tutorial and Kobby Maven Tutorial.

What will we get in the end?

If you are too lazy to read the whole article…

Query

https://medium.com/media/e40b8c3ef4c62e3e7d9168767b2fa292/href

Mutation

https://medium.com/media/1ba2bec8364da1939fa23e05a4f3cee6/href

Subscription

https://medium.com/media/425b555882d7f11f5cd1ad609cdde709/href

Kobby Plugin setup

In the beginning was the Word…

But we will start with a schema of our service. By default, the Kobby Plugin looks for a GraphQL schema in files with graphqls extensions in the project resources. For the sake of simplicity, we will place our schema in a single file named cinema.graphqls:

https://medium.com/media/f64c75ea428a7f0b4eb485daad7a0fdb/href

This simple schema will allow us to try out all kinds of GraphQL operations — queries, mutations, and subscriptions.

Next, we have to configure the plugin. For Gradle projects it looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/b18e5bdd00cb732d0422fd6553f4c7e1/href

For Maven projects, this does not look so elegant:

https://medium.com/media/e6673b3c0b0309887b89e82e88451ac8/href

There are explicit and implicit ways to configure the plugin. We used the implicit way by adding dependencies to the Jackson and Ktor libraries. The Kobby Plugin not only scans resources for schema files but also analyzes project dependencies. If Jackson is present in the dependencies, then the plugin adds Jackson annotations to the generated DTO classes to ensure JSON serialization. If Ktor is present in the project dependencies, then the plugin generates a default DSL adapter. We’ll talk about adapters in the next section.

Instantiate DSL Context

We have configured our plugin. Now we have to generate a DSL according to our schema. Run gradle build for Gradle or mvn compile for Maven and the plugin will find the cinema.graphqls file and generate a DSL based on it:

The plugin will create the cinema.kt file with the cinemaContextOf builder function that instantiates the CinemaContext interface — the entry point of the generated DSL:

https://medium.com/media/d2dde37955f7c94f3daa4114ad210154/href

We have to pass an instance of the CinemaAdapter interface to the builder function to create the context. What is an adapter? The DSL context, generated by the Kobby Plugin, knows nothing about the transport layer and GraphQL communication protocol. The context implementation just builds the query and passes it to the adapter. And the adapter has to do all the dirty work — send the query to the server, and receive and deserialize the response. You can write your own adapter implementation or use the default adapter generated by the plugin.

We will use the default adapter. It uses Ktor to execute GraphQL queries and mutations over HTTP and to establish subscription sessions over WebSocket:

https://medium.com/media/68b80809c3bd69e8fab33a7eee2417d1/href

Executing Queries

We are ready to execute our first query. Let’s try to find a film with actors by ID. In GraphQL, this query looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/55699cbd99b393d532e83763774934df/href

In Kotlin, it looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/5c13e4679815e07740245251f3b135a6/href

The context.query is suspending function, and does not block the current thread. What do we get as a result of executing the query? In GraphQL, the result is JSON that looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/7b343c938ed065791ba80938da87046f/href

To navigate through the result, the plugin generates “entity” interfaces that look like this:

https://medium.com/media/334ac21b2a1a696854090b0014abbf00/href

The context.query function returns an instance of the Query entity, so the navigation through the result looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/6e4469981c8088d428ec62c865ba261c/href

Executing Mutations

Let’s create a new movie. In GraphQL, the mutation looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/c50dbd01be2155d39e00b45495d646d2/href

And we’ll get the result as a JSON that looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/d0ef3077cacf9546c1ad906c3bee99a2/href

In Kotlin, this mutation looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/690c6a75662470accd3d1cf8e9d1bda1/href

The context.mutation function returns an instance of the Mutation entity interface and also is suspending function. So, our mutation does not block the current thread.

Establishing Subscriptions

Let’s subscribe for new films notifications. In GraphQL, the subscription looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/643a888a3e5a7722de148280e7ccbbfc/href

With this subscription, we will receive JSON messages that look like this:

https://medium.com/media/465ac18cd25d0725b61bb2084b65acb0/href

The semantics of the subscription operation in Kotlin is different from the semantics of the query and mutation operations. While the query and mutation just send a request and receive a response, the subscription creates a long-lived session to listen to incoming messages. So, we have to create an asynchronous listener to receive incoming messages:

https://medium.com/media/f11f5f2c786219d8fa7af3905bfbe830/href

Don’t worry, we are not blocking the thread in an infinite loop, because the subscribe function and the receive function are suspending functions.

The lifetime of the subscription session is the same as the execution time of the subscribe function. When we enter the subscribe function, a session is created, and when we exit it, the session is destroyed.

The receive function returns an instance of the Subscription entity interface for each incoming message.

What have I not covered in this article?

  • I haven’t covered how to map scalars defined in a schema to Kotlin datatypes.
  • I haven’t talked about how the plugin works with abstract data types.
  • I haven’t covered how to customize the generated DSL using GraphQL directives.
  • I haven’t talked about how the plugin supports server-side development.

And most importantly, I didn’t talk about how to use Kotlin extension functions to turn the generated DSL into a rich domain model on steroids. Perhaps I will cover this in future articles.

content.value:
Introduction

Hi everyone 👋 I will try to explain Jetpack Compose Fundamentals and Why should I use Jetpack Compose. Jetpack Compose is important because it is a new way of building modern UI in Android. Let’s dive into the UI development in Android without XML.

In my opinion, Jetpack Compose is the future of Android UI development and we must adopt fastly.

What is Jetpack Compose?

Jetpack Compose is Android’s modern toolkit for building native UI. It simplifies and accelerates UI development on Android - Google

Jetpack Compose is a modern toolkit that allows us to build our screens in a declarative approach writing less code. Android UI Development is now more powerful and more decoupled.

Before Jetpack Compose, we were using XML layouts to build the native UI. We had a very dependent structure when we build the screens with XML. Also, fragments are very heavy components for the UI. Jetpack Compose allows us to build the same UI with a declarative UI approach and with less code.

Why should I use Jetpack Compose?

In my opinion, it’s more than easy from XML and Kotlin ❤️

If we look technically:

  • Declarative UI is cleaner, readable, and performant than Imperative UI.
  • Compose allows you to do more with less code compared to XML.
  • Compose is Intuitive. This means that you just need to tell Compose what you want to show the user.
  • Compose is compatible with all your existing code: you can call Compose code from Views and Views from Compose. Also integrated with many Jetpack Libraries.
  • Compose improves your build time and APK size.

XML Design vs Jetpack Compose

Composition — Recomposition — State Management

Each composables has a initial compositon. Initial composition runs only when we see a view at first time in screen.

Composables can hold a state and re-run on state changes. This is called Recomposition.

Atomic Design

In Compose, component inheritance is implemented with functions, because composables are functions. A composable function can only be called with in another composable. As we write smaller composables, we get a more flexible component structure.

XML vs Jetpack Compose with Code Samples

1. Basic UI Components

Now let’s build the same view using Xml and Jetpack Compose and look at the differences on the code side.
Here is the target view structure:

Build with Xml

https://medium.com/media/6d80eef191694147abeb5c9dafd9de48/href

Build with Jetpack Compose

https://medium.com/media/ea8c90e50b9246930ff2cdb80979d048/href

2. List Items

Build with Xml

We need a few file/class for showing a list in screen with Xml:

  1. adapter_item_list.xml
  2. ListItemAdapter.kt
  3. ListItemViewHolder (inner class)
  4. Populate activity/fragment

Build with Jetpack Compose

We need only LazyColumn for showing list items in screen. No needed adapter class or item design xml file. We can describe item design in item/items scope.

https://medium.com/media/485323a678a8ef94168f1af7ebabfa29/href

State Management

“State in an app is any value that can change over time.”- Google

Compose is declarative so the only way to update it is by calling with different arguments.

Initial Composition: creation of a Composition by running composables the first time.
Recomposition: Re-running composables to update the Composition when data (state) changes.

Store a data with remember:

val data by remember { mutableStateOf(INITIAL_VALUE) }

If you want to keep data when configuration changes, you shold store data with rememberSaveable:

var tite by rememberSaveable { mutableStateOf("") }

In my opinion, Jetpack Compose is the future of Android UI development and we must adopt fastly.

What is Jetpack Compose?

Jetpack Compose is Android’s modern toolkit for building native UI. It simplifies and accelerates UI development on Android - Google

Jetpack Compose is a modern toolkit that allows us to build our screens in a declarative approach writing less code. Android UI Development is now more powerful and more decoupled.

Before Jetpack Compose, we were using XML layouts to build the native UI. We had a very dependent structure when we build the screens with XML. Also, fragments are very heavy components for the UI. Jetpack Compose allows us to build the same UI with a declarative UI approach and with less code.

Why should I use Jetpack Compose?

In my opinion, it’s more than easy from XML and Kotlin ❤️

If we look technically:

  • Declarative UI is cleaner, readable, and performant than Imperative UI.
  • Compose allows you to do more with less code compared to XML.
  • Compose is Intuitive. This means that you just need to tell Compose what you want to show the user.
  • Compose is compatible with all your existing code: you can call Compose code from Views and Views from Compose. Also integrated with many Jetpack Libraries.
  • Compose improves your build time and APK size.

Kt. Academy is widely recognized as a publication about programming.

Currently, it has:

  • over 10290 subscribers on Medium,
  • over 4870 emails on our newsletter;

You might know us from articles about Kotlin and Android, but we publish different topics as well. Our mission is to promote programming in general and simplify its learning. To serve this mission even better, we invite you to write articles with us.

Why?

Cooperation with us will help you to grow as a writer. You will get from us:

  • promotion on our publication and all our mediums,
  • feedback about the article,
  • technical proofing for the article content.

Good content will help you get more popular and reliable as an expert. With good promotion and our support, your voice will be heard. You will be able to speak in an important cause or to promote important ideas you believe in.

What?

It does not matter if you are using Kotlin, Python, JavaScript, React, or TypeScript. Maybe you are great at Testing, Machine Learning, Android features, or other topics. Let us know!

If you have some idea for an article you want to write, you can first ask us if we are interested. Just send an email to contact@kt.academy.

How?

You need a Medium account to write for KA. Then create a “New story” and start writing. Here is a small to-do list before the article can be considered as finished:

  • The article should have an image. Set it as a featured image by clicking it and pressing Shift+F. It should be either a photo taken by you or one of the free images. Alternatively, you can add a description with the link to the website where you found it.
  • Re-check and re-think your title. It is very important to make it interesting.
  • Check the grammar of the article using Grammarly (copy-paste the content there).
  • Check your article using Hemingway editor.

When it is all done, then click the “Share” button at the top of the screen and copy the link.

Send this link to contact@kt.academy with information that you want to publish your article on Kt. Academy. We will review it and answer you.

We wish you good writing :)
